flowRoot.flowPara: # Post messages to a laconi.ca server (such as http://identi.ca/).
# Can be run interactively in terminal or used to post stuff directly
# When first run, it will try to set things up interactively.
# Quickly hacked together by Urpo Lankinen <http://www.iki.fi/wwwwolf/>
# Do whatever you want with this script, but don't remove this
# copyright notice. There's NO WARRANTY express or implied.
puts "Lacopost must be configured first. To reconfigure, edit or delete"
password = Readline::readline('Password (will be echoed; can leave blank to define later): ')
puts "Type 'quit' or press Ctrl+D to end the session.\n\n"
puts "ERROR: Message too long (#{l.length} bytes, max. 140)"

text.tspan: This thing is here just to tell the command interpreter this is a
Ruby program. Dead weight, otherwise.
And here's some helpful comments. Whee, we tell the user
what this program is. And here, we also tell how to get in touch
with me and under what terms you can distribute this program.
What fun! Useful information? Maybe a little bit.
This little widget is probably useless to you. it tells me when this
file was last modified.
And here we need some boring code libraries. Yawn.
A few constant values that might actually be used somewhere.
Now we come to the interesting part. As you can see,
the vast majority of this program is devoted to this
very very important part of this program. Very high
profile, very remarkable, very integral to the operation
of this horrible little program of mine. It is a very
important part of any program, as a matter of fact.
...It handles the settings. YES, SETTINGS.
Ordinary logic says that settings are easy, but to
make the settings easily changeable and manageable
and not hard-coded, you need to devote A LOT
of stuff for storing user preferences.
And here's a silly misdesigned part that I couldn't
remove, because the readline library doesn't have
anything like this and I was too lazy to do this properly
since the script is just for my use and you only need
to configure the program once anyway.
Here's a bit of COMPLETELY USELESS but neat code.
It makes the terminal window have a cool changed title when
this program is running.
Ultimately useless - but quite kind - soft-squishy-helpy-kindness user help...
Oooh! This program has actual error handling!
Here we actually report back to the user what this program succeeds in doing.
And here's the most surprising part of the program, the part that
you might have even missed if I hadn't pointed it out to you:
THE PART OF THE PROGRAM THAT
ACTUALLY DOES SOMETHING USEFUL.
We have the user name and password, website API location, and
message - now we need to post it to the site! Often, in programming,
the hard part isn't doing the thing itself; the hard part is to figure out
what to do and how to avoid the mistakes!
Here I've stored settings for two different text editors. In different formats, logically -
not everyone follows Emacs' lead.
